Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2014 05:25AM whatnow wrote: I'm stage I, not stage II, but I couldn't resist posting a bit of encouragement for you on this forum because I'm so frequently up at 1:45am (and 2:45am,and 3:45am, etc.).  I just have sleep problems in general. One of the things my brother told me was that he had a friend, a brilliant man, who finally "lost his marbles" near the end of his life because he simply could not turn his mind off.  I have that problem, and you say you do too.  When we lie down and the day winds to an end, there is nothing to do an no one to talk to, and no distraction to keep our minds off the "what ifs." Those are dangerous musings.  Sleep is so, so, so important.  And I don't think I slept more than, on a good night, 6 hours during the entire 18 years I raised my child alone. I paid for it in health problems.  I worry that the Internet is one reason so many of us suffer from these distracting "what ifs." I too had three tiny nodules discovered in May.  I was referred to a pulmonologist and finally got an appointment in August.  And, while trying to research online so I could understand the appointment (for example, my nodules are not calcified and that is a good thing for breast findings but it's not the optimum for lungs), don't you know I found an image on that darn internet that looked, I swear, exactly like my images, and it turned out to be mets from cancer somewhere else. It actually had three nodules, in the exact same places as mine, two rounded near the pleura and a more triangular shaped larger one, and all similarly sized as mine (I had my films so I looked at them myself and found the spots based on the report that was included). It was quite a bizarre coincidence. I tried not to worry, and I didn't much, but it was still always in the back of my mind.  Honestly, the appointment was silly to have even paid for (other than to set my mind at ease, which was priceless).  He did say we should probably watch for growth (another CT) at some time in the future (6-12 months), but he did nothing else and had zero concerns.  I don't know if he even looked at the copy of the images, possibly just read the report (since he's not a radiologist, after all).  He said, if any random ten people were grabbed off the street and given a scan, five would have nodules and most of those would be nothing to worry about.  Despite my light to moderate cough and severe shortness of breath, he did no other tests (he said we could do function tests, but didn't think they were necessary). Bottom line - it's easy to say but difficult to do - try not to worry until there is actually something to worry about - that's a recipe for causing an illness just from worry. Me?  I'm hanging in until November for another scan with truly zero worries now. Best to ya. Stay true to your course until you're knocked off.
Posts.Title: Can't sleep...1:45am. Sigh... Lori1967 Hopeful82014

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2014 01:39PM whatnow wrote: I've had several MRIs: breast, two brain MRIs, one spine.  If you've had a CT, they are similar, but take much longer.  If you've been prescribed something to relax you - TAKE IT. It works (if they prescribe enough).  If you've had any other MRIs, they're all similar.  Two of my four had "contrast" material (one brain plus breast).  It was much like Janett described.  You will take the relaxing medicine before you even start.  Then you will get an IV line started before you lie down. My own machine was a bit "upright" (unlike my other MRIs).  I had an "open" brain MRI and "open" spine (I have a bit of claustrophobia). Frankly, I don't think they help at all, AND the results are not as good.  I can't remember the specifics about how I got into my breast MRI, but it was slanted up, like and MRI machine turned sideways.  My head was completely out.  I felt like I was feet first into an "ice cream cone."   My MRIs have been anywhere from maybe 30-45 minutes up to a total of 1.5 hours.  But, if you have a closed machine, as Janett said, the techs will talk to you, they will either hear you of you can squeeze something to notify them.  It is truly not a problem.  If you have claustrophobia (and people have varying levels of course), what helped me was to realize that I was far from "trapped."  I could get out whenever I wanted. But I WANTED to be here.  I CHOSE to do this and I want GOOD results.  One of my brain MRIs, my neurologist gave me GOOD relaxation meds and I couldn't have cared less about any of it. The technicians are not legally allowed to tell you what is on the images. They are radiographers not radiologists (MDs).  But the results CAN get to your doc by the next day, if that's why he/she made the appointment in the first place.  Yes, they will look at both breasts. My MRI found a 2nd tumor in the same breast the day before my surgery.  I'd already decided on a mastectomy, but that would have been very luck for me if I'd decided on only a lumpectomy. Piece of cake. Really.  And then you can treat yourself to a piece of cake afterward if you want!
Posts.Title: Please describe your breast MRI CeciliaVera Trvler

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2014 05:36AM whatnow wrote: Not sure of course, but I just got a screening lung CT, and I recall them telling me "So, we'll let you know if we see gall stones or anything."  I said "What?  In my lung"?    She said "Oh, no, but the imaging will encompass other abdominal areas, and the radiologist reads whatever is put in front of him."  So, if they notice anything at all, they'll mention it. Best.
Posts.Title: Can someone explain this? lulu70 JacquiW

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2014 09:02AM - edited Nov 18, 2014 11:56AM by whatnow Many members have undergone a long path before reaching a "firm" diagnosis either way. The way to get through it is to put your mind on something else.  I know. Easier said than done. When I was in an acting class, we were asked to not think of a pink elephant. As you would imagine, that is the first thing on all our minds.  The only way not to think about something, is to replace it with something else.  Our minds aren't blank. So keeping busy is your best tool. When I had my first "questionable" mammogram (which was my very first screening exam, at age 40-41) - I got a snail mail (it was long ago) which said nothing except that I should call to set another appointment to further address the finding.  So I sat all night at home, single mother of a young girl, wondering what it meant.  Then, I had to wait weeks to get in.  I went through another mammo, an ultrasound, etc - and was finally pronounced healthy.  I practically ran from the office, feeling like I'd had a reprieve, not knowing how many times this happens.  Several years later and a finding comes from out of the blue (as they often do), in the other breast instead.  I was asked to wait a few months before re-addressing because my radiologist just wasn't sure (looking back, I now realize my ultrasound tech seemed much more concerned).  But I'd learned my lesson about worrying - it does no help.  And this was still not quite the Internet age that it is now (things have changed so fast!), and I did not go online looking up every possibility.  I do wish I'd been a bit better informed about my treatments (like chemo) - but it's only recently that patients have had access to so much data.  We used to rely solely on our physicians.  So, yes, months later and more mammos, ultrasounds, biopsy, MRI - it can be a long drawn out experience to a firm diagnosis. So try to hang in there, get busy, know that a lot of women (and men) go through this waiting.  The good news is...it's the hardest part of the journey - no matter which path you end up taking.
Posts.Title: Waiting for your life to change? ExpatriateGirl ExpatriateGirl

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2014 07:33AM whatnow wrote: MaryJC - mine are very tiny, and only a few (3-6?).  I only know this because I am switching radiology practices and asked for a copy of my records (they sent me everything, every original film, all reports, everything!).  I'd only previously talked with my radiologist about this finding in 2011. She wasn't really concerned at all.  And I'd never heard of birads until I saw the term on BCO.  Now that I have the reports, I see she rated them Birads 3 - PROBABLY BENIGN.  And each consecutive exam they went down to 2 and then to 1 because they haven't changed.  As for the "2nd tumor" - that was actually in my OTHER breast (the one on which I had a mastectomy).  I had a 1.8cm tumor, and I now know (from these reports - because you just KNOW I poured through them) that I also had a LOT of DCIS and the 2nd tumor was only 3.5 mm.  So I wish you all the best -
Posts.Title: Nervous! MaryJC MaryJC

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2014 08:22PM - edited Oct 25, 2014 08:23PM by whatnow Your calcium deposit data is interesting.  I have a little area like that, a few tiny specks, that barely made them look twice (said I could have a biopsy if I wanted, but....I didn't). They weren't really concerned at all. And they haven't changed for a few years so of course we now know they're fine.
Posts.Title: Nervous! MaryJC MaryJC

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2014 11:28AM whatnow wrote: I'm curious about those who posted that you are angry that others shared your news with their extended circle. Did you specifically ask them not to tell anyone else?  I ask this because I've had this happen before, and I've been on both sides of the situation.  If you did not specifically say "please don't share this," then I wonder how you can be upset?  Many people (and I include myself in this group) prefer not to have to repeat a thing like this over and over.  It takes some of the burden away if others share my story among themselves. That said, it's also bizarre to find out that, for example, one's hair stylist or grocery store clerk knows, and I begin to question how the game of "Telephone" reached so far.  But I would never be surprised for a relative to tell other relatives, or for my neighbors to share the story.  Wouldn't you consider it passive-aggressive not to tell each other?  Have you been on the end of the story when every relative or neighbor knew except you? Would the "patient" (or other subject of the story) wonder why all her loved ones were offering to help, but you never came to her aid?  Then it seems we are venting because that particular person didn't ask about us. I think we can all see the myriad sides of this social dance, if we take a moment to do so. That's tough to do when one is in the middle of the struggle, however.
Posts.Title: When diagnosed- did you share with family & friends? MamaM whatnow

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2014 08:45PM - edited Oct 7, 2014 08:48PM by whatnow I told everyone.  I couldn't see a reason not to. I was also at work, like many here. Monday morning, first call of the day was my radiologist. "It's a cancer" (I can hear her surprised and sympathetic voice right now). My sister worked at the same place so I went into her office and said "Well, I didn't get the results I wanted from that biopsy."  I asked her if she'd call our siblings so I didn't have to say it over and over. I told my 13 year old daughter of course, and coworkers.  I don't know how anyone would manage not to tell everyone, at least eventually, because sooner or later the majority of us will be hairless, going to doctors, having surgery and/or radiation, etc.  We might want to wait until all our options are in front of us before telling bosses, extended family, etc.  But we need support, and they can't help if we don't tell them we need help-that would feel a bit passive-aggressive to me. Though I wish my entire family hadn't come to the hospital for the mastectomy--I knew it wouldn't be a big deal--and it wasn't.  I was going to get a cab to the hospital (knowing I wouldn't be driving home), but, as I said, I worked with my sister so she insisted on knowing when it was and taking me.
Posts.Title: When diagnosed- did you share with family & friends? MamaM whatnow

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2014 06:37AM whatnow wrote: I experienced a lot of what you did. My very first mammogram involved a suspicious finding as well. After much additional testing, everything proved to be well. Six years later it was the other breast that developed cancer. And I was also sent home to wait it out and come back. One difference is that my doc did not think it was cancer, so it was quite a surprise. So there is probably not much anyone here can say to calm your fears.  It's normal to be afraid of the "what ifs," as my daughter used to call them.  But try not to let them consume you until you have all the facts. Try to have a wonderful, activity-packed Sunday with your hubby. The most important thing right now might be that you not let your mind, as you say "prepare for the worst."  Because, as you know, if you do get the dreaded diagnosis, you have already been given some really good news. It's probably small; it's probably not in the lymph nodes. And this forum is jam-packed with women who were diagnosed in that same situation and cancer ended up just being a bump in the road of our journey.  OK, a teeth-jarring bump, but manageable. So many of us expect the worst outcome when we hear the "C" word - but know that it's a very well-researched, treatable disease.  We live in a time when we're lucky that it's often discovered early, and that many types are, as my oncologist put it, for all intents and purposes - "curable." I'm glad you came here.  When I recently poured out my soul to a sister about a problem I'm struggling with, she said that telling someone else cuts your own pain in half.  I don't know if that applies to this, but it's still good to "get it off your chest" as you said (see, you're still subconsciously making puns!). All the best to you as you wait out the results, and then a plethora of hugs if those results are not what you'd hoped for.
Posts.Title: New here and just need to talk Siren40 AndreaR

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2014 06:47AM whatnow wrote: Just try to keep really busy today so your mind cannot wander off into the unknown.  You're nearly there, you'll have your answer soon (though I'm sure it doesn't feel like it). Best to ya.

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2014 05:57AM whatnow wrote: I am NOT a doctor, nor do I play one on TV.  So take anything I say (as well as everyone else on this board) with a giant sized grain of salt.  I was told I had dense breasts. That was when I was younger (though sill age 46 ish at diagnosis).  Making the story short-I no longer have dense breasts, just due to aging and the resultant hormonal changes. However, what I have noticed over these past 15 years of mammograms is that every doctor, technician, piece of equipment, medical practice - is different from the next.  I had one I loved. They did nothing besides diagnoses and biopsies.  I loved my doctor there, and my ultrasound tech.  I even had a woman there who did painless diagnostic mammograms-true story!  But, like so many health practices these days-they closed down.  I can't even blame Obamacare-it was before that started.  Over the years I've been pin-balled around to different places as one closed and then another and another as insurance practices changed.  My very first screening mammogram involved a suspicious finding, so I got ultrasounds with each consecutive visit, and I always got to see the doctor for her interpretation. Just when insurance no longer let me see the doctor unless there was a problem, sure enough, I got cancer so I saw her anyway.  After cancer, I always got ultrasounds because that is how my cancer was found (not through mammogram).  Then, because an MRI before surgery found a 2nd tumor, I was told o get MRIs every year (I only did one then stopped, it seemed excessive). My facility actually did mammograms of my mastectomy site, pulled the tiny bit of tissue left (no reconstruction) into the machine.  At some point, when I changed facilities, they no longer checked the mastectomy side at all. Then, with my newest facility, I was bum rushed through the appointment and sent on my merry way with no doctor, no ultrasound, no explanation (even though my prior appointment was borderline on whether we would biopsy a particular spot on my remaining breast, and I got to talk to that doctor about it to help me decide).  So, while my cancer was discovered by an ultrasound tech, and my doctor argued it with her before asking me to wait a few months and biopsy later--know that a radiologist is an MD, and an ultrasound tech is not.  For me, I'm going to be looking for a different facility next year because, although I'm not one to worry much when they tell me I'm fine--I still just didn't feel right about this last place I was sent to.  I'm dreading having my entire file transferred.  So find a place where you feel comfortable and know they're doing all that you want done, and try to feel good about their work.  It's not a perfect science, but we've come a long way (even in the past few years alone).  We're lucky that we live in a time with these diagnostic measures...but they can go too far.  Best to ya!!
Posts.Title: Can density change in 1yr from High density/risk to no density? Taylor24 Taylor24

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2014 07:43AM whatnow wrote: Yup, that "fall forward" is exactly the part that no one understands unless you're the one with the prosthesis. When I lament the wearing of "real" tops, people think I'm saying I can't wear "low cut" tops.  Oh no, girls...I mean I can't wear any of the things that YOU wear.  I'm not talking halter tops.  I'm saying I'm confined to T-shirt heights.  And camis are fine until it's the heat of summer and you're in two layers AND a big silicone blob.  But-it is what it is.  We have a new normal.
Posts.Title: Embarrassing Moment Today tinkers2 PT6

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2014 06:01AM whatnow wrote: I used to work with a woman who had her wig fly off at work once too.  She was working outside on a windy day and whoosh...there it went.  She never had much of a problem with her wig, she'd pull it off in the office.  She had a great attitude.  I mean, do MEN wear wigs if they have chemo?  OK, well maybe Brett Michaels (that's the name, right?  that musician who had long straight blonde hair and always wore a bandana?), but not those who aren't in the public eye/entertainment.  It's quite sad that women aren't considered "presentable" without make-up, shaved legs, perfect breasts, and acceptable hair.  I think we're turning a corner, but it's still a sad statement.  We are what we are and we're all beautiful. I got stopped going through airport security a few months ago.  Full body scan.  TSA agent said "I need to pat you down...(then glanced up at the machine that must have "lit up" near the prosthesis")...right HERE."  She actually pointed a bit lower on that side.  I explained that I wear a prosthesis.  She just patted me and I walked away. With all the hubbub about being mistreated at airlines and by TSA agents for so many reasons lately--I guess I got a good one. Because, as I picked up my stuff, she turned back to me and said "Are you a breast cancer survivor"?  I said yes. She said "Well that's great."  It was very nice of her to go out of her way.  I also just got a lung CT and I have a copy of it (to take to a pulmonologist).  So of course I popped it in my computer (and can't tell one thing from another of course). But, as I move through the slices I can watch my ONE breast grow and the other one never appears.  It's very odd.
Posts.Title: Embarrassing Moment Today tinkers2 PT6

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2014 03:16PM whatnow wrote: Cutting to the bottom of your post - yes, even though I had cancer previously, I have some microcalcifications in the other breast  that were Birads 3 and I didn't go back for a year, and there was no real concern.  They sort of left it up to me, asking if I was the type to want a biopsy or wait and see.  I waited.  I'm 3 years out and Birads went to 2 the next year and 1 the next year.
Posts.Title: Annual Mammo/US gets Birads 3... see you in a year? VanillaPudding sarahjane7374

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2014 01:17PM whatnow wrote: I'm so sorry you've been left to wait and wonder--especially on a holiday weekend. When will you be able to get in for the PET?  I have not had one, but, from what I've heard...don't plan on having a 100% answer from the PET...it sounds like they are known to have a large number of false positives and negatives.  I'm not really sure what else to say because you obviously need someone to HEAR you right now, and I am not a fan of those who pat us on the head and say "Oh, don't worry, I'm sure it will be fine."  Because sometimes it isn't. Regardless, right now you need a shoulder and I wish I could be there.  Everyone is on holiday so you aren't apt to get many responses.  I'm bored today (no plans) so I've been trying to catch up on things on the computer and heard your call.  So just have an adult beverage (if you're so inclined) and watch fireworks (if you like), and marvel at today.  Get yourself as many minutes as you can where you do NOT think about it, until it pops back into your mind uninvited.  Here's hoping your scan is clear.  If it's not - well, you're in pretty good company on this site - look around at some of the "signatures" on here.  SO many people who have lousy diagnoses and are living wonderful lives.  Best wishes for today and always.  One day at a time.  If that doesn't work for you right now, then one hour at a time, or one minute, whatever it takes until you get your answer.
Posts.Title: Lumps under right clavicle sheropesem Luvmydobies

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2014 02:53PM whatnow wrote: I didn't know anything about cancer when I was diagnosed and treated. I came late to research at the BCO (a nurse recommended it to me).  I'd already decided on a mastectomy (to avoid a 2nd surgery if "they didn't get everything," and to avoid radiation). For some reason, an MRI was done right before the surgery (to locate the tumor, which I thought odd since I was having a mastectomy).  Turns out it was a good idea anyway because there was a second primary tumor "close to but not touching" the chest wall.  I remember my surgeon saying "we got good margins," but not giving any type of number. She later told me that she had to "scrape the chest wall." Blech.  I think I'm glad not to have known any of this before it all went down.  So - I don't have a number; I just trusted her to have done her best.

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2014 06:38AM whatnow wrote: I also agree that a consult with a plastic surgeon is not unwarranted before consulting with the breast or general surgeon.  If, for example, the plastic surgeon tells the patient that he can "match" the new breast to the old, but then reminds her of something like "of course, when your existing breast begins to sag, or you gain/lose weight, it will change - but the reconstructed breast won't" - that might help a person decide lumpectomy or mastectomy.  Or maybe he will talk about a "faux" nipple reconstruction, etc.  I guess, as I type this, it still does seem that consult could come after the general/breast surgeon - but at least before making a decision.  We know that the general/breast surgeon needs to know if he/she is performing skin saving surgery, for example.  I decided on a mastectomy without a plastic  surgeon consult at all.  And I can't really recall my surgeon appt. providing me with too much info - though I'm sure it did.  Bottom line is - if you're feeling uncomfortable about your surgeon, that's a reason to shop around. But I don't think it's unusual to refer someone to see a plastic surgeon to have a talk, before deciding on a double mastectomy. They want you to know all your options and know what you're getting yourself into. Good luck on this tough decision. Best to ya.
Posts.Title: Dr seems to keep wanting to do consultation over phone Sinclair whatnow

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2014 01:47PM whatnow wrote: Jennie:  I am "lopsided" as well.  Know this, there are laws that your insurance company must cover a procedure to make your breasts "the same." (not intended as a legal description!!).  At least, that's how I understand it.  I feel your pain about the bra.  Problems come up that are hard to understand by people who haven't lived it.   I've considered removing the other breast as well...then I chickened out.  OK, I'll just say it...because I didn't want to lose the nipple and its...sensation.  It's about my favorite part of my body. There, I feel like I just said "I'm "whatnow" and I'm a nipple-aholic."  Heehee. But it is quite a pain in the arse even to walk to the mailbox in a T-shirt when it is SO obvious without a bra. And "normal" tops?  Fuggetabout it.  It's not like I want to show cleavage.  But anyone with zero or two breasts can't know what happens when, even when wearing a prosthetic, we can't wear shirts that are lower than the clavicle. Bending forward can cause a clear view all the way to the navel too, when the prosthesis falls away from the body. Yes, yes, special tops and bras, prostheses that stick to the chest (I have one)--it's just hard to explain.
Posts.Title: New, scared, and sleepy WhiteTiger farmerlucy

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2014 01:52PM whatnow wrote: White Tiger:  I'm glad you'll have a social worker on your side for this procedure. It is indeed a horror story that you have family nearby that cannot or will not help.  It's easy for anyone to be confused with all the terminology and dates and numbers and people and procedures.  I went through all my diagnosis completely alone and I probably didn't "catch" everything. So you let that social worker help you, because we all need help sometimes.  Maybe she can help sort through this confusion.  Best to you.
Posts.Title: New, scared, and sleepy WhiteTiger farmerlucy

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2014 08:54AM - edited Oct 3, 2014 08:59AM by whatnow I wonder why some of us feel negatively about Pink-October?  I went through a brief period when I did too.  Not terribly, just a bit of "Oh, gosh, not another pink thing to watch on TV, see at the store, encounter at school," etc.  But then I realized that it is only because of this massive awareness push that we have the treatment options that we do. This money has funded the research that has saved the lives of many breast cancer patients.  I've never been one to participate in a lot of "rah-rah" type things like these. But, ironically, my daughter had decided to captain a team of 24-hour walkers for an American Cancer Association before I was diagnosed, and it took place when I was about two weeks out from my mastectomy. I chose not to wear a "survivor" colored T-shirt, because I don't like attention, but I came, set up camp, donated, walked in the middle of the night when the kids were all sleeping, donated.  As I was walking the track (it was at her Jr. High School), I was reading the luminaries placed all along the path (when one donated, a candle was placed in a bag and one could write the name of a lost loved one or survivor.  I read my name, twice.  I didn't know until later that some parents of the other kids had put my name on it.  I didn't even know they knew I had cancer!  When I lost a co-worker and friend only a few years after she was diagnosed, but I was spared, I wondered why. I didn't know why she wasn't taking any "pills" after her surgery (she got a lumpectomy and radiation), when I was going to take them for 5 years.  Since then, after it went to her brain and killed her, I found out she probably had er-/pr- cancer, and the treatment options aren't often as successful as anti-hormonal treatments for us er+/pr+ gals.  My oncologist said - there is just not as much research on that type yet.  I don't like it when people put up Christmas lights at this time of year either, and when they don't take them down until March.  But, while Pink-Tober might seem like overkill--we have a long way to go in researching, preventing, and treating this beast (as well as many others). I think it's so huge because nearly everyone has been affected by it (themselves, a loved one, a relative).  So I embrace those who want to climb on board and help fund treatments and cures.  So I say bring it on.  I don't do much myself.  I donate every time I can.  I buy things that are pink if I happen to need them anyway, knowing I'm paying a bit extra so it can be donated.  Of course a large chunk goes to operating the organizations who run the program; that's always true in varying degrees. If one has worked in any non-profit capacity it's evident.  It's true when one buys a $1000 a plate fundraiser dinner for a candidate, it's true when we buy girl scout cookies. I know the Susan B Komen organization was hit with a bad leader and has been trying to come back from that.  There will always be good and bad charities within any fight. I even donated healthy breast tissue from my remaining breast for a large research tissue bank in my area.  And I wear a little pink ribbon lapel pin every October.  From the 1st to the 31st.  Every year without question. And I'm thankful for those who participated in the "rah-rah" of Pinktober because it probably saved my life. I see no reason to be angry about it.
Posts.Title: October.... The cosmic joke Swegirl Hopeful82014

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2014 06:23PM whatnow wrote: I'm sure every situation is different. Seems you've already covered the big thing - to take an advocate with you.  I did not care for my first oncologist's bedside manner (and later switched).  But I guess that's what one gets with a statistical genius type, and that's really what we want.  Hard to find a great scientist in the same body as one who is caring about strangers.  Anyway...all I remember is his asking me what made me decide on a mastectomy (versus lumpectomy and radiation).  I said that it was a numbers game for me. They can tell me that the odds are the same, but I'd have to undergo radiation if I did a lumpectomy, which has its own problems, and then there was the possibility of 2nd or more additional surgeries if the margins weren't clear or there was another recurrence.  I'm all about "just get it out"!  I'd ALREADY had my surgery before meeting him - I know that's not true of every type of treatment so that makes a difference I assume.  Anyway, he said he'd explain it to my by the numbers. He used a white board and wrote a ton of odds all over it - all of which I forgot.  He taped his speech so I could review it later (something I'd been advised to do but wasn't prepared, but then he did it for me as a matter of course).  I didn't have anyone who could go with me, so it was quite a lot of scientific info.  Then I guess he scheduled sent me to be scheduled for my first chemo.  I saw someone say they had an HOUR long appointment!  Wow, I wasn't in his office for ... 15 minutes?  Or maybe I'm just not remembering it well.  It was the easiest of all appointments because there was no pain! Best to ya.
Posts.Title: What Do I Expect from Ist Oncology Visit? MaggieCat labelle

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2008 10:08AM whatnow wrote: My friend was diagnosed one year before me.  She now has lung mets, and recently discovered brain mets.  Her tumors are large, upsetting her balance, etc.  She was actually out of town working when they were diagnosed.  As you said, the worst headache ever, didn't go to work so they checked on her at the hotel.  How awful to be out of town without family when one is first diagnosed with mets to brain!  Anyway, lots of long story about that nightmare week. But, she's been undergoing WBR - maybe 10 ish treatments?  She'd already undergone 2 chemos and I think two courses of radiation.  More than one surgery, etc etc.  But this WBR...and I think primarily the steriods to reduce the swelling...definitely knocked her on her butt.  Her fatigue is extremely intense.  She worked through all her other treatments!  But she can't stay awake (and focused) more than an hour.  She can't stay awake at all for very long.  She has mouth sores that hurt when she eats BUT is always hungry from the steroids.  Anyway, her radiation has ended and I THINK her fatigued has lessened SOME.  The woman tried to drive!  Her doctor yelled at her of course, as she still has a lot of balance/stability issues as the largest of her tumors is one one side and she tends to lean toward that side.  But I agree that I think it's the steroids that seem to be the hardest on her.  She does continue to have bad headaches.  The pain medicine is helping that some.  She also has the digestive problems.  They're on hold to determine the next course of treatment as they've yet to measure her shrinkage progress.  I just wanted to pass on that her symptoms do sound a lot like your Mom's.  I was driving my friend to a store the other day and she also "moaned".  It seemed without reason and scared me a bit.  But then she went right back to talking and making sense.  But she's MUCH better than she was when they found her at the hotel...not even making any sense and unable to get out of bed.  So...going through the tough treatment seems to be working.  I hope it does so for your Mum as well.
Posts.Title: MOM NOW HAS BRAIN METS! cneal318 TripleNeg

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2014 12:05PM whatnow wrote: Bosum:  Whenever I go to any new doc or technician, even though they have my chart that undoubtedly says "mastectomy, no reconstruction," I always try to prepare them, specifically because I don't want to see that astonished face.  It's worked well so far.  I've said it many times (as I will today when I go in for a chest CT), and they've always responded kindly with words like "Oh, don't worry about it, we see everything."  But I know that, if it was instead a surprise, they might reacted in a startled way--so I still prepare them every time.  Then they can put on their game face and I don't have to see the alternative.  I specifically recall that the tech for the heart echo for chemo was also my very first person I told.  It was a young man and he was very sweet.  I mean, I'm not afraid of mice either but I'm still startled and scream like a little girl if they run up my arm when I'm trying to push down the trash in the trash can (yep, true story dat). I had a young cousin who was born very early and he had a clef lip and his skill had not closed.  I remember being "prepared" for what I was going to see when I looked at him through the nursery window.  But I was only about 14 years old and I was so startled I had to walk away and try not to let myself cry.  I was ashamed of my reaction, but I couldn't stop it.  His mother would come and feed and rock him at the hospital, and the nurse on duty would try to convince her to sit away from the window so no one could see them.  I remember her saying "I'm no ashamed of this baby."  Of course not, and I'd feel the same, and I'm glad she refused.  But it was still a sight that could still be quite startling to those coming to visit. All the best to you - I hope you never have to endure that discomfort again.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2014 03:07PM whatnow wrote: When I got my injection before surgery, I was told they could put something numbing in it (lidocaine?).  I cannot remember why they did not do it - I only remember the fact that they didn't. Because there were two people in the room at the time (I went down to the bowels of the hospital to nuclear medicine, and the nurse who escorted me, as well as the person giving the injection, were both there. It hurt.  Of course. But it is a very minor thing when compared to the whole of our situations.  And, I can't imagine how a numbing agent injected with the shot would really help with the pain of the shot.  Perhaps, for some, they can do a topical numbing agent, like the dentist does?  I don't know. But I do remember the technician (or doctor, or whatever he was) saying that it's better not to have it anyway - and that it actually can make it hurt more because it's just all that much more volume they have to inject. That made sense to me. At any rate - it was not a big deal.  I'm glad I wasn't researching and worrying ahead of time.  It had to be done anyway. It wouldn't be made better by knowing and worrying instead of just jumping in at doing.  I hated it when an endodontist had to show me pics and explain in detail about my root canal.  I don't want to think of the specifics. He said he was required to explain.  I tried to just ignore him and nod my head. The more I know about the body parts and how the process is (the injection in my breast, the surgery, the root canal) - the more I have a chance to obsess about it.  I like to be ignorant.  That said, since you want to know...I think I had more than one injection, but it was such a small blip that I am not sure.  It hurt, but no more than numbing shots in my mouth.  I knew I just had to breathe and tough it out for a minute or two.  That said - my injection was NOT in my nipple.  That must make a big difference.  I did have to wait, but maybe only for a half hour. I did not massage anything.  I did bleed a lot.  I was embarrassed because I got back to a holding room and family was there. My sister immediately said "Well, I guess they did something because you're bleeding."   I was bleeding through my gown. It was an odd comment, and thanks for bringing everyone's attention to it.  I think she was just nervous too.  No one knowing what to say really.
Posts.Title: Radioactive Injection into Nipple NOT TERRIBLE waynesgirl50 Motherofall6

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2014 11:19PM whatnow wrote: Swegirl: I get your point.  While some of us are in a bad mental state, others are wearing with pink ostrich feathers and giggling and running or buying or eating - and it can feel like "they" just don't "get" it (on our bad days). But a lot of those people are also survivors, and they're celebrating the help they received, embracing the fact they are here to join the fight to help the next person who walks down the path they've already walked.  It can seem like it's just all so "pc" to be involved - but that can actually help the cause.  When my daughter was first learning to donate her time (for any cause) in honor society...the kids were often required to meet a certain number of hours, or encouraged with rewards to volunteer.  I remember saying to my sister, who volunteers about as many hours as she works, and both are full time - that the kids should learn to want to volunteer just because its the right thing to do. She wisely said "and they will, but they're new to all this, and it is how we encourage them to participate.  Later, they'll see what their help meant to others, then they'll continue volunteering.  This is just a start - to open their eyes to service.  Pinktober can be like that.  Just think how little we all knew about breast cancer when we were diagnosed. For many of us, even if our neighbor or co-worker, aunt or friend has been diagnosed...we don't really know anything about what they went through. It's an education, and it's money for research.  If it's excessive, and seems too much like a party at our expense, we should try to embrace the help.  But, again, I feel you.  I hope you see better days.  Best to ya.
Posts.Title: October.... The cosmic joke Swegirl Hopeful82014

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2014 05:05PM - edited Oct 10, 2014 05:08PM by whatnow It IS indeed temporary.  But still no fun as we go through it.  I thought hats looked horrid on me, and I refused to wear a wig because I felt they all looked like wigs.  I decided to just "go with it," yet I could not manage to be bald in public. I had a collection of scarves that I tied different ways. Today, a woman could go bald and some would think it was just a fashion statement.  Not many do it, but I'd think about it if I ever had to face that challenge again.  I didn't think that being bald would bother me much. But, when I was at the "pulling out handfuls" of hair (and I had LONG hair), I went on my lunch hour and had it shaved (I'd developed two bald spots that morning anyway).  I had to turn away and not watch it happen.  I'd brought in a hat to be ready, asked them to turn my chair away from the mirror (afraid I'd peek, I guess), slipped on my hat and did not look until I was home alone that evening. I ended up writing a non-fiction report on how important our hair can be when I went back to school last year. Oddly, I moved my bandages and peeked just as soon as I woke up from my mastectomy, and didn't really feel as bad as I did about my hair. Those feelings certainly changed later, since the hair is temporary but the missing breast wasn't.  But, today, I have long thick locks again (at age 55!).  And, if encouraged a bit with "curl" products  - I still have some of the curl I had when it first grew back in (I had a bit of body or wave beforehand, but was never curly). I once saw a bald woman with a scarf on in the grocery store. She was in pretty rough looking shape as far as her health. So I said, quietly "I used to have that hairstyle."  I'm also so glib about everything, but I forget not everyone is like me. At first she didn't understand and her eyes flashed in anger as she was about to say "I have cancer!"  But then I saw the understanding come over her and she seemed to nearly weep that someone (who had regrown a mane of long, thick, shiny hair) understood what she was going through. Best to you.  YOU are not your hair.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2014 09:26AM whatnow wrote: Welcome (though it would be better if you were out watching your kids play soccer, or participating in some gardening or retail therapy).  A 3D mammo!  Wow.  I've seen those on TV but I've never had one myself.  I don't really know anything about them yet - I hope it can be used, in your case, to show that "all's well."  Best to ya!
Posts.Title: New to forum. Not Dx'd. RFM68 RFM68

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2014 05:42PM whatnow wrote: Going to a doctor will not cause you to have a condition (you know that already, but I mention it because you have a fear of going and being told that you have something late stage and scary like your Mum...and I definitely get that).  But it can help either confirm a diagnosis or ease your fears. You're obviously concerned, so you should definitely have it checked.  Because you're young, start with your GP/PGP perhaps? An urgent care doc is not really the best option for a condition that sticks with you (in my opinion).  We can't know if there is a "cause for concern," but I think you've already answered your own question just by asking here.  You should go to your primary care doctor and explain the history. Hugs and best luck.
Posts.Title: Real symptoms or just paranoid? LisaLCA Islandgirl17

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2014 06:30PM whatnow wrote: Pattyshot...: Of course I have no idea about YOUR situation.  The closest I came was when I had my mastectomy.  I came away with a gorgeous scar, no stapes or stitches showing, it had just been glued.  I didn't even know it had been glued except that something kept flaking under my armpit (the scar goes from sternum to axillary/armpit area), and I didn't understand what it was.  It was just flaking off like a bit of dried super-glue.  For ME, my incision was not affected.  I ALSO was told by the surgeon to set an appointment when I was draining "x" number of cc's (or less) from my drains.  I was very anxious, so I called the very day it happened.  I knew I wanted to get in very soon because I'd heard that the longer they're left in, the more difficult they are to remove. But they said they could not see more for another 10 days or so (I'd stopped draining maybe a week after surgery, so waiting an EXTRA 10 days meant MORE than doubling the time, and I didn't know how that would affect me).  So I explained that the doctor said I needed to be seen within "x" days of reaching my drainage goal (she had given me some number, but I don't know what it was), and they "found" some time to see me (I mean, it only took a 10 minute appointment for follow up and drain removal).  I know 10 minutes multiplied by a ton of patients is a lot of time, but she doesn't see that many patients.  Best luck to ya.
Posts.Title: 7 mm mass directly under nipple Pattyshothouse whatnow

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2014 08:49PM whatnow wrote: Ohhhh.  Gosh, I don't know.  Mine started flaking within maybe a day.  But that was under my arm, I didn't really SEE anything at all on the area that used to be my breast.  I was AMAZED that I looked "healed" the very day I went home. But I think that is unusual.  I am complimented by docs on my scar all the time (well, my surgeon is complimented).  But mine was a mastectomy; I'm sure they're very different procedures.  I am flabbergasted a doctor's office is saying they won't see a patient who needs to be seen. We know there are only so many hours in the day, but then they shouldn't overbook.  That's just a recipe for a lawsuit.  "Ummm..yeah...memba when I called begging to be seen and you refused to see me"?    Wonder if you should call and say it IS looking infected (one of the nurse's qualifying conditions).
Posts.Title: 7 mm mass directly under nipple Pattyshothouse whatnow

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2014 09:56AM whatnow wrote: Not speaking to you?  What is she ? 14 years old?  I know it doesn't count, but you've found 500 cyber friends who know where you are coming from. I tend to think that people who behave this way are those that would react the most opposite if they were in your shoes. We cannot change how others respond, we can only adjust ourselves.  I was once at a party, only a couple weeks after my mastectomy.  A woman who know I'd had the procedure came up to hug me.  I crossed my right arm across my chest (to protect it, kind of like how guys who are shaking hands sometimes hug, dunno if I'm explaining that well), and hugged her with the other arm and said "oooh, just gentle, OK." She pulled me in HARD and said "Oh my gosh, this doesn't hurt!"   In other word, I was being a real baby, in her mind. I didn't bother me much, but did stick with me. About 7-8 years later, her husband told me she was going through breast cancer (her second type of cancer).  We saw each other at an event and she pulled me aside and said "I just wanted to apologize for the time I didn't believe you about your pain."  That was a very nice thing to do, but it had to happen to her before she understood (and she didn't have a mastectomy). People are like that.  Nothing is a big deal until or unless it is their deal. The world is full of ego-centric personalities. It's natural, I guess.  But, with some effort, we can all see that, even if we are each the center of our own universe, each other person is also the center of their own.  I wish you all the best. Cling to your friends who care and understand that you are a valuable friend who needs support.
Posts.Title: Just need to vent LexiGirl33931 shimmermtl

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2014 11:21PM whatnow wrote: Justneedinfo: I feel your pain.  I had a similar diagnosis, was age 46, and was also a single Mother (though my child was already in Jr. High and did not have developmental challenges--I know those are BIG differences). I did have siblings living near the same city where I live, but they did not help me. So, while I cannot begin to know how difficult this has been for you--I do know that you'll get through it.  Because we do what we have to do to get through the day. So now, you don't "just need info," you need some tlc. I also worked full time.  I had my own business so there were NO "sick days"  (I had no other employees). But I had to take time off, there was no choice.  Myclients were very understanding, so I was inordinately lucky.  I ended up missing Wed-Fri only for my mastectomy, and the same time for chemo (I quit chemo after 1 treatment). I have to pay for my own private health insurance-still do-and I had no prescription coverage.  Before that--I didn't miss anymore more except for appointments (MRIs, biopsies, etc.). With surgery-I missed only one of my daughter's events (a band concert).  Chemo was harder because I have a VERY weak stomach. I could eat only a few things, and my daughter was no help (yes, I know, she SHOULD have been by that age but I hadn't taught her any cooking-I asked if she could just make me some rice once and it was inedible-not done-heehee). But now, it's 8 years later an my daughter just graduated college and, guess what, I did too!  (OK, I actually have about 2 assignments left this summer).  So I wish I could be there to give you a hug. I'm sure your Mom will do everything she can.  Hopefully social workers can help you answer any other concerns you might have. So you'll get through it as you have so far with that wonderful baby--one day at a time.   Hugs and best to you.

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2014 05:55PM whatnow wrote: I still have a crazy intense itch in the axillary area on the side where I had my mastectomy and lymph nodes removed.  I hate to say this but I'm 9.5 years out!  However, it's not the annoyance it was in the beginning. And, though there is numb"ness," it is not completely numb and I absolutely dig my nails in to relieve it.  But I know what y'all are saying about not being able to relieve it.  I'm more like that around my back. Kind of like that itch that is somewhere between your ear and your mouth...in between and drives you crazy.  I've assumed my axillary itch is in the area where my few nodes must have been removed. Definitely the least of our problems, eh?
Posts.Title: Will I ever stop itching? Held Moderators

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2014 10:07PM whatnow wrote: I'm so sorry that you now have more than a casual, browsing reason to be a "member," of this club. However, you're lucky to have found this site early.  You asked for guidance about your upcoming appointment.  I would recommend two things: If possible, ask someone to go with you, and always ask for copies of your reports/records (diagnoses, pathology). You couldn't absorb all the info (numbers and terms) they'll throw at you over time.  You'll want the paperwork to refer to, and the advocate both B`as a second set of ears, as well as support. Best to you on this tough journey; come here whenever you want info or support from those who've traveled before you. But, just as one an never step into the same river twice--every journey through this path is also different for everyone.

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2008 08:13PM whatnow wrote: I vote for the Tamox.  Of course everyone has differing reactions to each step in this game.  But SO many people have stiffness with Tamoxifen that it's surely the suspect for you.  I myself had horrid stiffness.  I had NONE beforehand.  Not prior to dx, not during chemo, etc.  But only a couple/few months into the Tamox and WOW. Mine was mostly wrists and hands.  I did about 3 years on Tamox.  I've recently switched to an AI.  I still have stiffness to I don't know if it's residual Tamox of the AI. They're known for it too. Now it goes up to my elbow and shoulder and sometimes feet/ankles.  So...I guess it's a "small" price to pay but it makes for  a lousy quality of life.  However...if that's the only SE you get...count yourself lucky.  I know my worst on Tamox was debilitating fatigue. I am MUCH better on an AI as far as the fatigue.

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2014 07:54AM - edited Oct 8, 2014 07:57AM by whatnow Many, many women, both on this board and off, have and/or had enlarged axillary nodes.  That is a cause for you to have them checked, but not a cause for alarm. I know it's easier to say it than to do it, but try not to let trouble in the front door just because he's knocking - make him break the door down if he wants in.  I know you've already been diagnosed; what have your doctors said?  I think you're considering double mastectomy.  They'll be checking and removing the sentinel lymph node (and undoubtedly more too).  Relax first, get it checked out, then go forward.  All the best to ya.
Posts.Title: Scared- & question about lymphs MamaM whatnow

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2014 06:29PM whatnow wrote: Hey now, y'all....those diagnostic mammograms hurt us smaller chested women too!  Heehee.   Seriously, shewolfpg: What a rotten roll of the dice.  I'm glad someone referred you to this board.  There are a lot of answers here, no judging, and all the cyber-hugs you can handle.  Come here when you want to talk to people who understand. You'd be amazed how many people on here are/were otherwise healthy at diagnosis, and had no family history, and for whom breast cancer was quite a surprise.  I want to address your comment about how you're just getting used to being retired and stateside, and that you "thought fun was about to happen."  Yes, you're in for a delay in those plans, but that fun WILL be happening, and you might find you appreciate it even more later on.  Look forward to those plans.  Hang on to them so you can have goals to get you through the lousy days). A small side note...this forum is about YOU.  But I want to sneak in a very quick "please thank your husband for his service." Best luck; keep us informed.

Posts.Title: Would you mind sharing your age at time of diagnosis? ByFaith Gussy

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2014 08:13AM - edited Oct 18, 2014 08:15AM by whatnow Over the past 9 years, I have been moved around a lot from one health care facility to another as the keep going out of business. Recently, I was not really very happy with the place I was sent to, so I requested my records so I could go to a place of my choosing next year.  They sent me EVERYTHING.  I was amazed.  I'd never seen anything like this. From my very first exam 15 years ago, where I was called back for something suspicious that turned out to be nothing, through my actual cancer diagnosis later (in the other breast, by the way), all the way up to my most recent report.  Of interest, this particular facility did not include my mammograms from this recent visit - hmmmm. ?  Anyway, as you can imagine, I poured over the reports and films, and learned a lot of things I hadn't known before.  Things no one ever told me. When I was diagnosed, I knew nothing like everyone on here seems to know.  I knew my tumor size, stage, grade, and that I was ER+, PR+.  But one of the things I heard everyone talking about online was BIRADS.  I'd never heard of it, and thought it was new. Turns out, it's all over my chart but has never been mentioned.  What I'm getting to is that, I seem to have something different and slightly suspicious every time I go in for an exam, but we keep an eye on it and it never amounts to anything terribly concerning. In 2011, we began to "watch" something.  My doc at the time blew it off, but said "now, I don't know you very well yet.  If you're the type who wants to, we can go ahead and biopsy, but if not, then we'll just give it some time."  I am NOT the type who likes to worry where I don't have to, or be too invasive if my doc doesn't push it.  I figure they'll tell me when they think I've nudged over the border into a situation where I need a biopsy.  I looked back at that report and it was BIRADS 3.  So I looked that up and it says 'PROBABLY BENIGN FINDING." As a matter of fact, the report says she asked for a short interval exam the next time, but she didn't tell me (or I guess the schedulers) because I didn't go for another year. So I wish you all the best.  I'm glad you're taking care of your health. But MANY MANY biopsies are benign (I hate to quote so I won't, but I'm pretty certain it is the very large majority).  That is not to belittle your concern. I hate when people say things like "Oh, I'm sure you're just fine," because we aren't all "just fine."  But try not to let the worry overtake you.  Keep busy, and soon I hope you'll be looking in the rearview mirror at this situation.
Posts.Title: New here.... I am scared!!! Susanjoyr Kalonis52

Posts.Title: can i demand Oncotype Dx testing zha-an kris1114

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2014 01:28PM whatnow wrote: Hopefully others will chime in, but I don't believe there is really anything for you to "ask" at the ultrasound.  It's not really like an appt. with a family care physician. I'm only speaking of my own experience, mind you, but the ultrasound technician is not an MD, and most are not even allowed to speak to you about anything they did or did not see.  After the ultrasound is done, the procedure will vary based on your results, combined with the practices of the office you're visiting and your health insurance.  If there is no finding, I know that my insurance does not even allow me to see an MD (the radiologist at the office) for her interpretation/impressions. So, if there is a "finding" (still doesn't mean it's cancer), the radiologist might see you to explain what she wants to continue to watch, or what she thinks it is, or what she would want to do. Otherwise, you might be sent on your merry way, skipping off to treat yourself to lunch (here's hopin'!). While there are exceptions to every rule, please comfort yourself knowing that breast cancer at your age is less a very slim possibility.  I believe I've heard that it is less than 1%. I am thrilled that awareness campaigns mean we're all very vigilant in watching for signs of change in our breasts, but I do sometimes worry that we've been pushed toward the edge of a cliff just a bit, and we're "over-worrying."  Saying that you want them to "let [you] get a biopsy" should not be the goal, necessarily.  Definitely stick up for your own medical needs, but they are professionals whose job it is to seek out cancer.  If they do not find any, I hope you can be comforted and believe them enough to at least wait a bit before jumping into an unnecessarily invasive procedure. That said, I'm glad you're seeking a diagnosis, no one should completely ignore symptoms like yours.  But try not to worry if you can help it, until there is a reason to worry.  Your symptoms could mean a variety of things.  I wish you all the best.
Posts.Title: What to ask at an ultrasound? wonderboots wonderboots

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2014 09:10AM whatnow wrote: I'm not sure why I was never offered oncotype testing.  I heard about it only after joining BCO, well after my diagnosis, surgery, etc. But, at that time (9.5 years ago), I was told that insurance never covered it and that I'd have had to pay for it myself anyway. I don't know the answer to your question - but, since you're a lot more aware than I was - if you want it, surely they cannot refuse it. Oh, wait, they're "MDs," so they can do anything they want. A discussion is in order, then perhaps a second opinion if your doc won't do it, or allow you to at least understand why s/he feels it isn't necessary. Can the RO order it??
Posts.Title: can i demand Oncotype Dx testing zha-an kris1114

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2014 11:59PM whatnow wrote: Alien: Well, you certainly do have a good attitude. And you're right--at least, compared to a lot of diagnoses, IDC is a good type of breast cancer to have because it's well researched so there are a lot of treatments and great prognoses. Keep researching and maybe have some fun with the kiddos before surgery and radiation, as you'll be tired for a bit after all that.  Many feel like the waiting to know is the worst part, and I agree.  I remember getting my phone call with my diagnosis, and I just thought "OK, well, that's that.  Now what do we DO about it"?   We just move on to the next thing.  My daughter was 14, I was single with a full time job and terrible insurance that I paid for myself.  Now, she's just graduated college and so have I!  So you hang in there and take it one day at a time. Hugs.
Posts.Title: Highly Suggestive of Malignancy AlienWish angelaisscared

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2014 04:28PM whatnow wrote: For now, you "only" have to get through tonight.  Treat yourself. Cry if that helps you.  Or have an "adult beverage."  Or do research into the wee hours.  Or snuggle under a blanket and watch a movie-thon until dawn.  Or hug everyone you know.  Or whatever gets you through the night.  (I don't REALLY recommend staying up all night; you'll be getting SO much information tomorrow. But, let's face it, sleep might not come easily anyway unless you have something you can do or take to relax. Unless you're like me.  I wasn't a cryer--I'm very pragmatic and analytical). Then take a breath and dive in again tomorrow because you'll want your wits about you.  Take a loved one or friend if you can find one and they're willing.  Ask for copies of your reports so you can look at them by yourself later because you won't remember everything they say.  Then have ANOTHER night off.  And maybe even the weekend!  OK, you won't be able to stop yourself from thinking and talking and researching and wondering and deciding.  You'll have been given options, and they may feel like night versus day.  Maybe you'll need to make another appointment once you've thought about things. But don't feel like you're under the gun to jump into a decision.  Take your time. This didn't happen overnight and it won't change overnight. And, about 5 years from now, you'll be on here giving this same advice to someone else.  Best to you.

Posts.Title: waiting is over suzy129 Loulee

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2014 09:17AM - edited Oct 5, 2014 09:18AM by whatnow I can remember this happening to me as well.  The pain was not awful, but it just never ended.  I didn't heal the same way I healed with my cesarean section, for example. It was a different, annoying pain.  I was working, but "self-medicating" (cocktails every night so I could sleep) - NOT a good answer. I am also very slow to heal (I had a root canal 3 months ago and I'm still in some pain). I think, all we really want is to know that we WILL get better.  We can deal with the pain, as long as we know we're on the right track. If that's how you're feeling - then know that I realized I was MUCH better with a legitimate prosthesis than a soft one.  The soft one is not heavy, of course. But it moves and rubs and - blech!  But the real one sits tight and feels SO much more real.  I second the opinion of whoever said to massage it. I know it's counter-intuitive ("don't touch it , it hurts!").  Because I could not even allow myself to brush my fingers across it, but I noticed I could allow a doc to examine it without any problem. The first time I had to permit that I was petrified.  Afterward, I thought...hmmm...that wasn't bad a all. So I forced myself to touch it more, from the edges, softly over all of it, etc.  It took a long time, (more than months...I'd say years) and I will have the numbness forever, but the pain is gone.  But, then, we all experience different things.  No one can know what you feel, and if you need pain relief then you just do. Good luck to you.
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy Pain Syndrome (PMPS) Deeds Lezza13

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2014 02:38PM - edited Jul 12, 2014 09:46AM by whatnow "If it was cancer you would know" is indeed an unprofessional and highly questionable comment for an MD.  Many, many of us has zero symptoms and no clue when we were diagnosed with breast cancer (me included).  Yes, the waiting is hard--many say it is the hardest part (me included). I will never understand the reasoning behind not telling patients over the phone if they have a positive (malignant) biopsy. It's "old school" and does not change the outcome.  There will be many questions, of course, and perhaps they don't want the patient to be alone, or spiral. But we could hear it in a comfortable setting, and do research so we'd know what to ask, and not be in so much shock if they would all tell us as soon as they knew.  My own doctor did. She called me first thing Monday morning and didn't bother with that silly "we need to make an appointment" nonsense.  It's a power/control thing and I don't understand it. Instead, she said "it's a cancer," AND told me what I needed to do next.  However, know that most of us did have our share of waiting as well.  It's a science, but nothing is exact.  They don't want to say "yes or no" until they feel they KNOW, either way. My very first mammogram had a questionable finding. Even though that was only 15 years ago--it was so different than things are today (of course, every diagnosis, doctor, office, lab - - all do things differently).  I left the screening mammogram and thought all was over.  I got a LETTER (snail mail) that gave vague info, and said to call back for additional tests.  So it was already weeks later.  Then I had to wait until office hours to call, weeks for an appt., I had a diagnostic mammo, then ultrasound, then another ultrasound.  Each time there were days/weeks between.  And when I did finally get a cancer diagnosis (in the other breast!), my doc asked me to come back in a few months, and even then only reluctantly scheduled a biopsy.  I waited a long time too. It's tough-we totally understand. But I think it's GOOD that it's a long wait.  That means it's not a cut and dried "yes." Try to hang in there (though it's hard to hear that). I wish you the best. HUGS!!
Posts.Title: Not diagnosed but questioning dr armywife13 armywife13

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2014 01:03PM whatnow wrote: Holeinone: My situation was like yours - my radiologist did my core biopsy. But I've noticed that a lot of places do not do that; one is sent to the surgeon for the biopsy (I assume that would be especially true if excisional, not core). I didn't even realize the doctor who diagnosed me was a radiologist until I looked her up recently. This is probably because I always got an appointment with her during my mammogram/ultrasounds (that is not being offered by my current office, due to insurance, even if there is a finding!) - and because she did the biopsy. So, Memeral - do not think that being referred to a surgeon is a diagnosis yet...it is not. Best to ya.
Posts.Title: worried MemereL LexiGirl33931

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2014 03:36AM whatnow wrote: I can understand your frustration, and feeling like you have no control. You can ALWAYS vent here.  But it will also help you to realize there is no great rush for these processes. As I mentioned above, I was not sent to a surgeon until after my biopsy, but I think some people have a WLE type biopsy and I THINK that's done by a surgeon.  I really can't comment on all that because I was dx nearly 10 years ago and things have already changed. I was lucky to have a really good experience with my initial diagnosis and radiologist/biopsy, but I do not have that with most doctors. Everyone is losing money today and the patient seems to get squeezed more and more.  I've been treated with such disdain by the office staff of so many doctors I don't even want to go anymore.  They don't stop to realize that will make their financial situation even worse. But, back to your annoyance.  I was pretty ignorant when I was dx.  And ignorance CAN sometimes be bliss.  The Internet has provided a lot of info, but steered a lot of us without MDs in the wrong direction too (another reason doctors' offices all seem so touchy lately - we're questioning them and they don't like that). But it is certainly easier just to sit back and follow doctor's orders without realizing others have taken different paths.  While I don't counsel you to do that, I do hope you can find some peace by understanding that it's not an exact science, there are plenty of false positives, and you're getting there.  It may be slower than you want, but it's not completely necessary to understand everything on your reports. It's easy to make ourselves a bit crazy by looking too closely. I have some lung nodules we're watching to see if they grow.  I got online and immediately saw 40% of nodules are cancer. It took a bit before I realized that was a completely bogus number, and I have almost zero reason for worry.  If I'd just waited for my pulmonologist appointment (but 3 months is a long time to wait without any research), I'd have instead heard him say that about 50% of every person has nodules.  So hang in there, you'll get your answer.  I hate that your time has been wasted, and I know you're anxious.  Best to ya!
Posts.Title: worried MemereL LexiGirl33931

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2014 10:50AM whatnow wrote: I'm so sorry you've joined the ranks.  I'll try to be brief.  First, it's apparent you're quite intelligent, so don't jump to treatment decisions until you know about your particular situation.  Ask for copies of your reports, because you're obviously well researched from your past scare. Read about how different posters feel after having mastectomies, reconstruction, chemo.  Then listen to your docs' suggestions, and research more, and go with your own gut.  But, even with reconstruction, for example, there are different types. And, I had chemo even after a modified radical mastectomy.  I was able to avoid radiation by having a mastectomy, but not chemo. There is just so much to know.  FYI, I worked through my treatment and surgery with a few days off each time, and, at age 55, I'm finally completing my undergrad work (not postponed due to the cancer-I'm just saying that your education WILL continue).  I am an English major and I did write a paper that included how we identify with our hair more than we realize.  I was happy to have the cancer cut out, yet the mastectomy proved hard on me. But I wasn't worried about my hair (it will grow back, duh), but it was more traumatic than I thought. Depending on your treatment, you may not feel up to doing what you could do before.  Everyone reacts differently to each step in the process. After my mastectomy I didn't even take any pain killers and was at work three days after.  BUT, a double mastectomy is very different. We can get by without full use of one arm. Both at the same time?  Different.  As for chemo-fatigue can be an issue.  Nausea, confusion. My own problem was extreme nausea.  Even a few days later when I returned to work (I had no choice)...I sat with a wastebasket at the ready (but I never threw up after the first 3-4 days). That's extreme-most don't react that way. The anti-nausea meds didn't work.  I'm the type that throws up after EVERY surgery, with many meds (antibiotics, codeine, Demerol, any medicine that puts me out, etc. I even threw up when I had a doctor tell me I had to start eating meat again-blech!). I ended up quitting chemo, and found out that not all oncs would have made me do it anyway, and then had another onc who said the 5 years I spent on adjuvant therapy was much more important than the chemo.  So...? So, take the time you need to learn, digest, decide, change your mind, learn more. And never second guess whatever decision you make, because we cannot know the future.  You and your team will factor in SO many things (grade, stage, oncotype, size, age, health, hormone receptors, etc etc) before deciding.    For now, try to take someone with you to appointments (if you have one, I didn't) who can listen and write things down.  There is SO much to absorb. And don't be in a hurry (I was; I was worried because I felt there was no telling when that first little cell would want to go exploring all over my body with all its crazy friends like it was Spring Break). And come back here because no one "out there" understands like those who have been through it. Best to ya.
Posts.Title: It was confirmed today (33 years old). Kelly1217 whatnow

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2014 08:32AM whatnow wrote: Oh, BrittPro - I am so sorry that you've had to join the club.  It seems the diagnoses are on younger and younger women all the time!  But, at least your proactive approach means you've found it and now you can fight it.  I wish you all the strength and good fortune that the universe can roll into a gift-package for you to help make up for this lousy situation. Best to ya.
